home.title: UNDER CONSTRUCTION - Developing Identifiers for Heritage Collections
home.content:
This resource describes the different facets of developing persistent identifiers (PIDs) in the context of Heritage Collections.

Before you begin...

This resource is aimed at senior technical stakeholders within galleries, libraries, archives and museums to assist with developing requirements and advocacy for new services. Have a look at the [Read Me|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Read%20Me.html] section before getting started.

[##]

This resource will be revised in 2021 and maintained until the conclusion of the [Towards a National Collection|https://www.nationalcollection.org.uk] programme in 2025.

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.

Icons: Server, Protest, Robot, More information and Social Media on [Freepik|https://www.freepik.com], Plus by Vectors Market, Book by Payungkead, Globe by turkkub and Map by Dinosoft on [flaticon|https://www.flaticon.com].

Aspects.title: Aspects for Developing Identifiers
Aspects.content:
This page contains links to the aspects for developing persistent identifiers for heritage collections. For more information about this resource, see [Read Me|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Read%20Me.html].

[##]

Augment.title: Augment with existing identifiers
Augment.content:
Externally-created persistent identifiers are included for items and entities within metadata

Explanation

PIDs such as Wikidata IDs, ISNIs, Getty URIs, DOIs, Gazetteer URIs and IDs from other collections can be added to collection management systems. These can be included for related collection items, an identifier for a collection item itself where it is represented in another identifier scheme and authority files.

Benefits

  • Links with other collections.
  • Reduces workload of creating institution specific authority files.

Dependencies

[Baseline|https://francesmadden.github.io/PIDResources/Read%20Me.html] required.

Compatible PID Types

  • Wikidata IDs
  • Getty URIs
  • Gazetteer URIs
  • Digital Object Identifiers from other collections
  • Handles from other collections
  • ARKs from other collections
  • URIs from other collections

For more compatible identifiers, see Which persistent identifier does what?

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.
Augment.content right:
Examples

The Library of Congress provides links to other identifiers in its [names identifier file|http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n79041870]

[National Galleries Scotland|https://www.nationalgalleries.org/art-and-artists/artists/paul-gauguin] and [Moma|https://www.moma.org/artists/5047] in New York integrate Getty ULAN records and Wikipedia data into their artists’ web pages.

Supporting Materials.title: Supporting Materials
Supporting Materials.content:
This page contains links to supporting materials and guidance to help in using this resource.

[##]

Read Me.title: Read me - how to use this resource
Read Me.content:
Getting Started

The aspects are arranged in a general progression but a single institution would not have to implement all of these aspects.

Dependencies refer to other parts of this resource only. They mention the other aspects which would have had to have been implemented in order to implement that aspect.

Compatible PID types are included where the aspect describes an externally facing aspect of implementation.

All aspects require a baseline collections system to be in place.

The Baseline

Identifiers assigned within the metadata for physical items and/or digital objects. The identifiers are not globally unique, machine readable or resolvable. This is where we assume most users of this resource will be and the various facets build on this.

Explanation

This is what most organisations use now. These could be accession numbers, archive reference number, barcodes, internal database identifiers. The identifiers might be used in different systems but there is no computer interaction between systems using the identifier.

Benefits

You can use them to find items within your collection, however often they only work across one type of collection, e.g. you cannot search the museum collection management system using the archive reference number. Internal reporting is possible.

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.
Read Me.content right:
Examples

Any museum with a collection management system such Adlib, TMS, Emu etc. will meet this baseline level. Archives using a management system such as Calm. Libraries using a system such as Aleph or Alma.

PID Functionalities.title: PID functionalities - which persistent identifier does what?
PID Functionalities.content:
Please note

Identifiers which exceed the criteria stated are labelled as FALSE. N/A is used when the identifier is a maintained registry which is not readily open for contributions.

Identifier NameDescriptionBaseline ImplementationAugment metadata with existing IDsID which could be persistentCommit to persisting IDsHuman readable PIDsMachine readable PIDsGlobally resolvable PIDs
ARKs Archival Resource Key, a PID infrastructure for digital objects, that can be locally installed FALSE - exceeds see note TRUE FALSE - exceeds see note TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE
CETAF Stable Identifiers Consortium of European Taxonomic Facilities scheme of identifiers for specimens FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE
Dewey Dewey Decimal Classification is a proprietary library classification N/A TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
DOI Digital Object Identifier, a globally governed PID infrastructure. DOIs are particularly used for research-related objects FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE
EIDR Entertainment Identifier Registry Association, provides universal identifiers for movie and television assets, based on DOI infrastructure N/A TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
Geonames A database of geographical names combining data from multiple sources N/A TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
Handle A distributed PID infrastructure for digital objects, that can be locally installed FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE
ISBN International Standard Book Number, a product identifier for text based monographic publications TRUE TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
ISNI International Standard Name Identifiers, for disambiguation of authors, creators and copyright holders (as both individuals and as organisations) FALSE TRUE FALSE N/A TRUE FALSE TRUE
IGSN International GeoSample Number. IGSN’s are used by the earth sciences community for physical samples, and make use of the DOI system. FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE TRUE
LSID Life Science Identifiers, for data resources FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE
MDA Codes Managed by the Collections Trust, MDA Codes identify UK collection holding organisations and their collections TRUE TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
ORCID Open Researcher and Contributor ID, for disambiguating research authors and contributors FALSE FALSE N/A – assigned by individual N/A N/A N/A N/A
ROR Research Organization Registry, identifiers for research organisations N/A TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
PURL Persistent Uniform Resource Locator, a dereferenced and persistent URL for digital objects, managed by the Internet Archive FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE
UMID Unique Material Identifier, provides a method of identification for instances of audiovisual material and thus enables the material to be linked with its associated metadata N/A TRUE N/A N/A N/A N/A N/A
URN/URI Uniform Resource Name / Uniform Resource Identifier, identifying objects within a given domain or namespace FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE
UUID Universally Unique Identifier, used to identify information in computer systems FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE
VIAF Virtual International Authority File, combines multiple authority files from libraries around the world into one service N/A TRUE N/A TRUE TRUE N/A N/A
Wikidata Provides human and machine readable structured information. The central storage of structured data of the Wikimedia projects FALSE TRUE FALSE TRUE TRUE TRUE FALSE

Feedback

We value your feedback on this resource. Any suggestions on the content or additional examples would be welcome.

To submit feedback, you can raise an [issue via Github|https://github.com/FrancesMadden/PIDResources/issues] (requires an account) or you can use the Feedback button in the bottom right of each screen.
